{{Infobox political party | colorcode = #3063A5 | leader = | foundation = 1997 | ideology = [[List of pensioners' parties|Pensioners' interests]] | headquarters = | website = | country = Denmark | name = Active Pensionists | native_name = Aktive Pensionister }} '''Active Pensionists''' ([[Danish language|Danish]]: ''Aktive Pensionister'') was a political party in [[Denmark]].
==History== Active Pensionists was established in 1997.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Joerg Chet Tremmel|title=Young Generation Under Pressure?|date=2010|publisher=Springer Verlag|author=r Seán Hanley|location=Berlin|url=http://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/19144/1/19144.pdf|accessdate=7 May 2016|chapter=The emergence of pensioners’ parties in contemporary Europe}}</ref> The party ran in [[Danish local elections, 2001|2001]] in [[Copenhagen Municipality|Copenhagen]] (507 votes), [[Frederikshavn Municipality|Frederikshavn]] (212 votes) and [[Skagen|Skagen Municipality]] (19 votes). They did not get any municipal seats.<ref>[http://www.kmdvalg.dk/kv/2001/ kmdvalg.dk 2001 results]</ref>
In [[Danish local elections, 2005|2005]], Active Pensionists ran in [[Greve Municipality]] (43 votes), [[Vejle Municipality]] (158 votes), [[Fredericia Municipality]] (679) and Copenhagen Municipality (232 votes). They did not manage to get any municipal seats.<ref>[http://www.kmdvalg.dk/kv/2005/adk.htm kmdvalg.dk 2005 results]</ref>
The party has not run for municipal elections since 2005, and is assumedly dissolved.

page.title: Chiran Peace Museum for Kamikaze Pilots

revision.text:
[[File:TokkouHeiwaKaikan.jpg|right|thumb|Chiran Peace Museum for Kamikaze Pilots]] [[File:Chiran high school girls wave kamikaze pilot.jpg|right|thumb|[[Chiran, Kagoshima|Chiran]] school girls wave farewell to a departing pilot with branches of [[cherry blossoms]]]] The airbase at [[Chiran, Kagoshima|Chiran]], [[Minamikyūshū, Kagoshima|Minamikyūshū]], on the [[Satsuma Peninsula]] of [[Kagoshima prefecture|Kagoshima]], Japan, served as the departure point for hundreds of [[Japanese Special Attack Units|Special Attack]] or [[kamikaze]] sorties launched in the final months of [[World War II]]. A [[peace museum]] dedicated to the pilots, the {{nihongo|'''Chiran Peace Museum for Kamikaze Pilots'''|知覧特攻平和会館|Chiran Tokkō-Heiwa-Kaikan}}, now marks the site.
==Airbase== The [[Imperial Japanese Army]] airbase at [[Chiran, Kagoshima]], with its two runways, was the principal kamikaze base during the [[Battle of Okinawa]]. Of the 1,036 army aviators who died in these attacks, 439 were from Chiran. Of the total number, 335 were classed as "young boy pilots" (少年飛行兵).<ref name="Official Guide">{{cite web |url=http://www.city.minamikyushu.lg.jp/contents/file/20110121145009.pdf |title=Chiran Peace Museum for Kamikaze Pilots (NB downloads slowly) |publisher=City of [[Minamikyushu, Kagoshima|Minamikyushu]] |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
==Peace Museum== [[File:Ki-43 Hayabuya Kagoshima Japan.jpg|thumb|Ki-43 Hayabuya]] In 1975 a museum was built to commemorate the lives of the pilots and document their "[[patriotism|patriotic]] efforts for peace".<ref name="Official Guide"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spn/kagoshima/map_plus_info/locations.html |title=Chiran |publisher=[[Japan National Tourism Organization]] |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Enlarged in 1986, exhibits include four planes: a [[Nakajima Ki-43 Hayabusa]], a 1943 [[Kawasaki Ki-61 Hien]], a 1944 [[Nakajima Ki-84 Hayate]], and a [[Mitsubishi Zero]] recovered from the seabed in 1980. On a personal level, the exhibit includes letters, poems, essays, testaments, and other artefacts; as well as photographs of the 1,036 pilots, arranged in the order in which they died. There is also the grand piano on which two of the pilots played the ''[[Moonlight Sonata]]'' the night before their final mission.<ref name="Official Guide"/>
==Other monuments== The {{nihongo|Tokkō Kannondō|特攻観音堂}} is a [[Buddhist temples in Japan|temple]] dedicated to the "Special Attack [[Kannon|Goddess of Mercy]]".<ref name="Official Guide"/> The [[Cult image|image]] enshrined within is a 1.8m replica [[Japanese sculpture|statue]] of the Yumechigai Kannon (夢違観音 Dream-Changing [[Kannon]]), a [[List of National Treasures of Japan (sculptures)|National Treasure]] at [[Hōryū-ji]].<ref name="Official Guide"/> The names of the kamikaze pilots are written on paper within her [[Womb Realm|womb]].<ref name="Official Guide"/> It was erected in 1955 thanks to donations collected by Tome Torihama, who ran the Tomiya Inn frequented by the pilots, and who sought to redeem their [[Collective memory|memory]] after the war.<ref name="Tome Torihama">{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,344136,00.html |title=Ascent of the Fireflies |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |author=Cullen, Lisa Takeuchi |date=26 August 2002 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> [[Tōrō|Stone lanterns]] dedicated to the pilots line the approach to the museum.
==Anecdotes== [[File:Statue of a Kamikaze Pilot.jpg|thumb|Statue of a Kamikaze Pilot]] * [[Second Lieutenant]] Fujio Wakamatsu wrote: "Mother, I have nothing to say. In my last moment, and my first act of [[filial piety]], I will smile and conquer. With dry eyes and knowing I have done well. Please offer some [[mochi|rice dumplings]] at our [[Japanese Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[Japanese funeral|mortuary tablet]]."<ref name="Official Guide"/> * Pilot Hayashi Ichizo wrote in his diary: "I will do a splendid job sinking an enemy aircraft carrier ... I read the Bible every day ... I will sing a hymn as I dive on an enemy vessel."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ohnuki-Tierney|first1=Emiko|title=Kamikaze Diaries: Reflections of Japanese Student Soldiers|publisher=University of Chicago Press|pages=173–174|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/K/bo3750674.html}}</ref> * [[Major]] Hajime Fuji, a training instructor, presented his petition to serve as a kamikaze pilot written in blood; his wife drowned herself and their children so that he should have no [[Tanha|conflicting ties]].<ref name="Official Guide"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2266173.stm |title=When death came before dishonour |work=[[BBC]] |author=Summers, Chris |date=7 October 2002 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> * [[Occupation of Japan|After the war]], "Two or three American soldiers jumped up on the planes and kicked them with their military boots. They ridiculed the planes with the following scornful words, 'Look! So those kamikaze fellows came against us with these piddling worn-out planes. Did they think they could win with these toys? How stupid!'"<ref>{{cite book |last=Sato |first=Sanae |title=Tokkō no machi: Chiran (特攻の町:知覧; Special Attack Town: Chiran |page=203) |year=2003 |publisher=Kojinsha |isbn=4-7698-0829-1}}</ref>
==Film== ''The Firefly'' (ホタル ''Hotaru''): popular [[Japanese film]] of 2001, directed by [[Yasuo Furuhata]] and centered around the character of Tome Torihama, who ran the Tomiya Inn in Chiran and treated the young kamikaze pilots as if they were her own sons.<ref name="Tome Torihama"/>
''I go to die for you'' (俺は、君のためにこそ死ににいく ''Ore wa, kimi no tame ni koso shini ni iku''): 2007 film with screenplay by Tokyo Governor [[Shintaro Ishihara]], based on his conversations with Tome Torihama, who died in 1992.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1543912/Japanese-film-to-show-nostalgia-for-bravery-of-kamikaze-pilots.html |title=Japanese film to show nostalgia for 'bravery' of kamikaze pilots |author=Joyce, Colin |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=26 February 2007 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/kamikaze-survivors-express-regret-and-anger-in-new-film-458450.html |title=Kamikaze survivors express regret and anger in new film |author=McNeill, David |work=[[The Independent]] |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/05/12/us-japan-film-kamikaze-idUST26213420070512?pageNumber=1 |title=Japan's WWII 'kamikaze' film sparks talk of peace |work=[[Reuters]] |author=Reynolds, Isobel |date=12 May 2007 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== On 15 August each year, the anniversary of the date on which [[Emperor Hirohito]] announced the [[Japanese surrender]], [[Uyoku dantai|right-wing groups]] drive through Chiran in trucks blaring [[Nationalism|nationalist]] [[Propaganda|messages]] and [[National anthem|songs]].<ref name="Tome Torihama"/> Over the rest of the year, up to a million visitors come to pay tribute to the fallen.<ref name="Tome Torihama"/>
==See also== * [[Bansei Tokkō Peace Museum]] * [[Japanese nationalism]] * [[Japanese militarism]] * [[Japanese Special Attack Units]] * [[Suicide attack]] * [[Cornerstone of Peace]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |last=Ohnuki-Tierney |first=Emiko |title=Kamikaze, Cherry Blossoms, and Nationalisms: The Militarization of Aesthetics in Japanese History |publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] |year=2002 |isbn=0-226-62091-3}}

{{merge|Sant'Egidio Foundation|discuss=Talk:Community_of_Sant%27Egidio#New_duplicate_article_found|date=September 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} [[File:Sant'Egidio.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sant'Egidio (Church)|church of Sant'Egidio]] in Rome, seat of the community of Sant'Egidio]] The '''Community of Sant'Egidio''' ({{lang-it|Comunità di Sant'Egidio}}) is a Christian community that is officially recognized by the [[Catholic Church]] as a "Church public lay association". It claims 50,000 members in more than 70 countries. Its main activities are:
* [[prayer]], centered on a reading of the [[Bible]] * spreading the [[Gospel]] to help people who are looking for a sense to their life. * service to the [[poverty|poor]], which is free and unpaid * commitment to [[ecumenism]] (the Community of Sant'Egidio is also ecumenical, though rooted in the Catholic Church) * [[Interfaith|dialogue]] with members of other religions and non-believers.
Created as an NGO in 1968 it acts in more than 70 countries.
Today the Community has expanded greatly since its creator [[Andrea Riccardi]] created it in 1968 and now has more than 50,000 members.
==History== The Community of Sant'Egidio was founded in [[Rome]] in 1968 by a group of Roman high-school students led by [[Andrea Riccardi]] in the wake of the [[Second Vatican Council]] under the papacy of [[Pope Paul VI]]. It is named after the Roman [[Church of Sant'Egidio]] (Italian for [[Saint Giles]]) in [[Trastevere]], its first permanent meeting place. Since 1968, the community has gathered each night to pray and read from the Bible, reflecting on the Gospel, eventually spreading throughout the world with a mission of helping those in need.
In 1973, Sant Egidio founded his first church in Trastevere (the first church in that community) and from that moment the community of Sant'Egidio grew all over the world with the strange custom of daily community prayer. From 1977-1978 began to expand between the different Italian cities and in the 80s began to spread across the different continents. On May 18, 1986, the council of the laity named the community of Sant'Egidio as "an international association of the faithful of pontifical right".
Their activities include setting up refuges for the old, hospices for AIDS patients, and printing a handbook titled "Where to Eat, Sleep, and Wash in Rome" as gifts to the homeless. The lay Catholic Community of Sant'Egidio is among global leaders on HIV/AIDS, running programs across Africa, pushing scientific research ''inter alia'' on mother-child transmission, and advocating passionately that everyone deserves the best care.<ref>Marshall, Katherine. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/katherine-marshall/aids-from-judgment-to-hope_b_1127943.html AIDS: From Judgment to Hope], ''Huffington Post'', 12/6/11. Retrieved 12/6/11.</ref>
The charitable efforts of Sant'Egidio also led it to be a well-regarded mediator in peace negotiations. In the late 1980s, the Community came to the realization that their humanitarian efforts in [[Mozambique]], then torn by the [[Mozambican Civil War]], could not succeed without peace. In 1990, the Community was accepted by the ruling [[FRELIMO]] and rebel [[Mozambican National Resistance]] as a mediator, playing a key role in the [[Rome General Peace Accords]] signed in 1992.<ref>[http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/organizations/community-of-sant-egidio "Community of Sant'Egidio", Berkley Center, Georgetown University]</ref> They continue peace initiatives in [[Algeria]] (notably the 1995 [[Sant'Egidio Platform]]), the [[Balkans]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], and other areas, in the belief that war is the "mother of every poverty".
The community of Sant'Egidio shows its commitment against the [[death penalty]] by maintaining penpalships with many Death convicts, collecting signatures for a [[Moratorium (law)|moratorium]] of executions and inviting cities around the world to take part in the [[Cities for Life Day]]. One of the members of the community spearheading the movement against the death penalty, [[Mario Marazziti]], published an English-language book on the topic, [[13 Ways of Looking at the Death Penalty]].<ref>{{cite book |title=13 Ways of Looking at the Death Penalty |first=Mario |last=Marazziti |year=2015 |publisher=[[Seven Stories Press]] |location=New York}}</ref>
The current president of the Community is [[Marco Impagliazzo]].
==Governance== Being a large community there are several positions: * '''World President:''' Charge of all the communities of Saint Egidio of the world (Rome, Italy) * '''National President:''' Responsible for all the communities in your country * '''President of the community (centers):''' head of the community building, responsible for organizing charity events, activities, solidarity programs. *'''Volunteers:''' People who present themselves without receiving any salary just to help those in need.
The President and the Council of Presidency are elected every five years by the General Assembly of representatives of all nuclei of communities (if there are several communities in that country).
==Works== [[File:Mapa_san_egidi_ff.jpg|thumb|Map of the world of the community of Santo Edigio]] Around the world there are many communities of San Egidio, each with their respective activities, but all united by religion, Although there are very different cultures in different parts of the world are dedicated to helping those in need especially to third world countries like (Mozambique, Democratic Republic of Congo, Bolivia), however, also help countries that are not so poor but with major economic differences or to help refugees. It is active in: *Europe: 23 countries *Africa: 29 countries *Asia: 7 countries *N. America: 8 countries *S. America: 5 countries
The community of Sant'Egidio has helped a number of countries and made large collections of money for the poor, as well as creating soup kitchens, language schools for migrants, medical centers, or centers to provide help, centers for the disabled and countless charities . Although in countries with problems this NGO always helps them in what they can in giving them food and place to live. There are several Volunteer programs that are dedicated to accompanying those people who are alone or do not have anyone to go see them.
== Community Santo Egidio in Cataluña == * '''Works:''' Dining Hall Solidario: This work is celebrated on Christmas Day and is a celebration in which in the churches that are with this community, the benches of the masses are changed by tables and benches so that people who can not afford to eat Christmas food Can, also to reunite families that have not been seen in a long time or refugees just arrived in Barcelona. * '''Young people for peace:''' It is a volunteer of different ages (minimum 15 years) that is trying to go every Friday to grandparents' residences to visit the grandparents who have left them there and no one visits them, that is done to be Feel happy * '''Objectives:''' Let the whole world have their point of view well on religion and its happiness even if they do not have many privileges.
==Awards== The Community of Sant'Egidio has received numerous honors and recognitions.<ref>[http://www.santegidio.org/it/pace/premi.htm Premi e riconoscimenti], santegidio.org {{it icon}}</ref> These include: * 1997: World Methodist Peace Award from the [[World Methodist Council]] * 1999: [[Niwano Peace Prize]] from the Niwano Peace Foundation * 1999: [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny Peace Prize]] from [[UNESCO]] * 2000: Formal recognition from the [[New York City Council]] for commitment to [[human rights]], in particular efforts to stop the death penalty * 2002: Nominated by the [[Parliament of Italy]] for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] * 2004: International Peacemaking Award from [[Search for Common Ground|Common Ground]]<ref>[http://www.sfcg.org/documents/articles/cgawards2004.doc "Scaling the Middle Ground"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040627154159/http://www.sfcg.org/documents/articles/cgawards2004.doc |date=2004-06-27 }} ([[DOC (computing)|DOC]] format), ''[[The Washington Post]]'', March 6, 2004; Page B09 (copy hosted by sfcg.org)</ref> * 2004: [[Balzan Prize]] for humanity, peace and brotherhood among peoples.<ref>[http://www.balzan.com/en/preistraeger/egidio.cfm Balzan award 2004 - International Balzan Foundation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060513035922/http://www.balzan.com/en/preistraeger/egidio.cfm |date=2006-05-13 }}</ref> * 2009: [[Karlspreis|International Charlemagne Prize]] recognizing Andrea Riccardi, the Society's founder, as a "great European" whose life has been at the service of his neighbor.<ref>[http://www.zenit.org/article-25291?l=english Sant'Egidio Founder Awarded as Peacemaker] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607234421/http://www.zenit.org/article-25291?l=english |date=2011-06-07 }}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Bangladesh.svg|150px]]}} '''Corruption in Bangladesh''' has been a continuing problem. According to all major ranking institutions, Bangladesh routinely finds itself among the most corrupt countries in the world.<ref name="anticorruptionportal">{{cite web|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/south-asia/bangladesh/show-all.aspx|title=Business Corruption in Bangladesh|date=December 2015|website=Business Anti-corruption Portal|publisher=Business Anti-corruption Portal|access-date=18 May 2016}}</ref>
Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 143rd place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perceptions Index 2017|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|work=www.transparency.org|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref> The public sectors conducted by the Government are the most corrupted sectors of the country.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Zafarullah|first=Habib|last2=Siddiquee|first2=Noore Alam|date=1 December 2001|title=Dissecting Public Sector Corruption in Bangladesh: Issues and Problems of Control|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A%3A1013740000213|journal=Public Organization Review|language=en|volume=1|issue=4|pages=465–486|doi=10.1023/A:1013740000213|issn=1566-7170}}</ref>
[[Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh|Anti Corruption Commission]] is formed in 2004, but is considered to be largely ineffective in investigating and preventing corruption because of governmental control over it.<ref>{{cite news |title=ACC largely ineffective |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/acc-largely-ineffective-25194 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=21 May 2014 |access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://govpoliju.com/anti-corruption-commission-and-political-government-an-evaluation-of-awami-league-regime-2009-2012/|title=Anti Corruption Commission and Political Government: An Evaluation of Awami League Regime (2009–2012) {{!}} Government and Politics, JU|website=govpoliju.com|access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref>
== Causes of Corruption == After splitting from Pakistan in 1971, Bangladesh was ruled by a series of civilian and military governments. Riots surrounding the 2014 elections resulted in hundreds of deaths and [[Freedom House]] changed the country's "political rights" rating from 3 to 4 (with 1 being best, 7 worst). This was only one incident, however, in a modern history of highly fatal political violence.<ref name=trans>{{cite web| title =Bangladesh: Overview of corruption and anti-corruption with a focus on the health sector| work =Transparency International | url =http://www.transparency.org/files/content/corruptionqas/Country_profile_Bangladesh_2015_Focus_on_health.pdf}}</ref>
The country's score for rule of law on the Worldwide Governance Indicators declined from 28.6 (on a scale of 0–100) in 2011 to 22.7 in 2013. Although Bangladesh has experienced notable social and economic progress since around the turn of the century, it remains one of the world's poorest nations, with 76.5% in 2010 living on less than US$2 a day.<ref name=trans/>
==Corruption by sector==
Bribery, rent-seeking and inappropriate use of government funds, excessive lobbying, long time delays in service performance, pilferage, irresponsible conduct from the government officials, bureaucratic intemperance have made public sector departments the most corrupt sectors of Bangladesh.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{cite journal |last=Khan |first=Mohammad Mohabbat |date=July 2003 |title=State of Governance in Bangladesh |journal=The Round Table |publisher=Taylor & Francis |volume=92 |issue=370 |pages=391–405 |doi=10.1080/0035853032000111116 |issn=0035-8533}}</ref> Public sectors in Bangladesh include police departments, fire departments, water supply, electricity, gas supply, education, waste disposal, health, transportation, administration etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bangladesh.com/public-services/ |title=Public Services in Bangladesh |website=bangladesh.com |access-date=25 May 2016}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=August 2016}}
A 2012 study found that 97% of MPs were involved in illegal activities, with 77% abusing their positions on local election boards, 75% abusing development projects for their own benefit, including accepting commissions in exchange for approving projects or programs, 53% being involved in outright criminal acts, 69% influencing procurement decisions, and 62% influential local elections.<ref name=trans/>
Fully 45% of Bangladeshis view political parties as corrupt, while 41% regard the parliament as corrupt. Only the police and the judiciary are viewed as more corrupt. Many politicians are regarded as out-and-out criminals, while the parties also "are believed to harbour criminals and terrorists," according to ''TI Bangladesh''. The parties routinely exchange party funds for favours or pay them out because of extortion. They also improperly use state funds to buy jobs, licenses, and contracts for party members and other purposes. Party finances are largely non-transparent; despite regulations requiring reporting to the election commission, reports are scanty or absent and non-compliance is rarely punished. Also, both the parliament and the political parties are under the influence of business, with 56% of MPs now being business people.<ref name=trans/>

=== Student politics === {{Main|Student Politics of Bangladesh}} In [[Universities in Bangladesh|public universities]] and colleges the student wings of ruling<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/24/opinion/dhakas-unruly-campus-partisans.html|title=Dhaka's Unruly Campus Partisans|last=Anam|first=Tahmima|date=23 November 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref> political parties dominate the campuses and residential halls through crime and violence to gain various unauthorised facilities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Edvantage/Story/A1Story20100822-233266.html|title=Student politics and its ugly side|website=news.asiaone.com|access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref> They control the residential halls to manage seats in favour of their party members and loyal pupils. They eat and buy for free from restaurants and shops inside their campus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/916797/violent-student-politics-wreck-bangladesh-campus-life|title=Violent student politics wreck Bangladesh campus life|date=17 August 2010|website=www.dawn.com|access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref> They extort and grab tenders<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/06/24/jnu-kabi-nazrul-college-chhatra-league-activists-clash-over-extortion-of-money-from-students|title=JnU, Kabi Nazrul College Chhatra League activists clash over extortion of money from students|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref> to earn illicit money. They take money from job seekers and put pressure on university administrations to appoint them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6a8670.html|title=Political Parties and Political Violence|date=1 May 1994|website=Refworld|publisher=Research Directorate, Immigration and Refugee Board, Canada|access-date=28 April 2015|via=UN High Commissioner for Refugees}}</ref> In government colleges they take money from freshmen candidates and put pressure on teachers and officials to get acceptance for them.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-125229|title=Admission trade nets Tk 1cr in 3 colleges|date=6 February 2010|website=The Daily Star|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/news/56470/chhatra-league-vs.-chhatra-league|title=Chhatra League vs. Chhatra League|website=Prothom Alo|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-123934|title=BCL men fight over 'admission trade'|date=28 January 2010|website=The Daily Star|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref> Some of them often involves in robbery<ref>{{Cite news |title=Muggers in action in city |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/muggers-in-action-in-city-20030 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=13 April 2014 |access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref> and rape.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Dhaka University expels student on charge of mugging a man |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/09/02/dhaka-university-expels-student-on-charge-of-mugging-a-man |newspaper=bdnews24.com |access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref>
== Government == Corruption abounds in Bangladeshi government offices. Many officials receive salaries without having any actual assigned work. Officials are recruited and promoted for reasons that are not objectively clear. Solicitation of bribes is common. In a 2013 survey, 76% of respondents said corruption was a problem in the public sector, and 39% said they had paid a bribe during the previous 12 months. Bribes were especially common when dealing with the police (72%), the judiciary (63%), land services (44%), and registry and permit services (33%). Bribes were paid to obtain a service (58%), to speed up service (33%), to express thanks (7%), or to obtain cheaper services (3%). These numbers, though unimpressive, mark a significant improvement over 2010.<ref name=trans/>
In 2010, then president [[Zillur Rahman]] pardoned twenty convicted murderers of Shabbir Ahmed Gamma. In July 2011, he again pardoned Awami League leader and convicted murderer Biplob.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-257572|title=Zillur too merciful|date=15 November 2012|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=28 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2014/03/05/26-removed-from-death-row|title=26 removed from death row|newspaper=bdnews24.com|access-date=28 January 2017}}</ref>
Prime examples of government corruption are [[2011 Bangladesh share market scam]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-246119|title=Hallmark loan scam under ACC probe|date=14 August 2012|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sonali Bank vs Hall Mark Group: An analysis |url=http://print.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/old/index.php?ref=MjBfMTJfMjNfMTJfMF8xODBfMTU0MDA3&feature=c3BlY2lhbHNOZXdz&na=QW5uaXZlcnNhcnkgSXNzdWUgMjAxMiAoUGFydCBUd28p |newspaper=The Financial Express |date=31 October 2013 |access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sunday-guardian.com/analysis/the-minister-has-a-hallmark-moment|title=The minister has a Hallmark moment|website=www.sunday-guardian.com|language=en-gb|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/12/opinion/bangladeshs-other-banking-scam.html|title=Bangladesh's Other Banking Scam|last=Allchin|first=Joseph|date=11 April 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/economy/news/48712/Banking-sector-%E2%80%98still-reels-from-post-Sonali-Bank|title=Banking sector 'still reels from post-Sonali Bank scam'|newspaper=Prothom Alo|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref>
[[Padma Bridge Scandal]], occurred in 2011, was the largest political scandal in [[Bangladesh]] that involved the ruling Bangladesh Awami League's government who allegedly sought a large amount money from the Canadian construction company [[SNC-Lavalin]] in exchange for awarding them the construction contract.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.observerbd.com/2015/12/12/125661.php|title=Padma Bridge Chronology|website=www.observerbd.com|access-date=29 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ebangladesh.com/3904|title=Timeline: The WB, Padma bridge & Abul Hossain|date=26 July 2012|newspaper=E-Bangladesh|language=en-US|access-date=29 January 2017}}</ref>
On 10 December 2012, some hackers hacked and posted the seventeen hours' of [[Skype]] call of chief justice [[Mohammed Nizamul Huq|Nizamul Huq]] on YouTube where he suggested that he was under pressure from the government to reach a quick verdict in the ongoing 1971 war crime cases against the country's senior opposition leaders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/770583|title=Bangladesh war crimes chief judge resigns over hacked calls|date=11 December 2012|newspaper=DAWN.COM|language=en|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref>
===Public services=== The public sectors are among the country's most corrupt. In few countries is bribery more common in connection with public utilities. Nearly six out of ten firms report that they have to offer bribes, "gifts," or facilitation payments in exchange for licenses or public utility concessions or to "get things done." Unclear, contradictory regulations abound, and are often exploited by officials seeking informal payments.<ref name=biz/><ref name="trans2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/cpi2015|title=Transparency International – The Global Anti-Corruption Coalition|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|website=www.transparency.org|access-date=28 April 2016}}</ref>
===Land administration=== Corruption is widespread in the Bangladeshi land administration. Most companies expect to make informal payments in exchange for construction permits. In a country where land is scarce, title disputes are common, and title registration takes much longer than is the average in South Asia. The collapse of an eight-story factory in April 2013 was the result of substantial building code violations, and highlighted the role of corruption in the issuance of permits and licenses and in safety inspections.<ref name=biz/>
===Tax administration=== The Bangladeshi tax system is highly corrupt. In no country is it more common to be charged irregular payments in connection with taxation. More than forty percent of firms surveyed expected to present tax officials with gifts. Because the National Board of Revenue is poorly administered, tax collectors are able to collude with taxpayers, accepting personal payments in exchange for lower tax rates.<ref name=biz/>
===Public procurement=== The awarding of government contracts in Bangladesh very frequently involves nepotism, fraud, bribery, and favouritism. Nearly half of companies surveyed expect to make irregular payments to secure government contracts. The Public Procurement Act, Public Procurement Rules, and other legislation are intended to guarantee above-board conduct in this sector, but they are at best poorly enforced.<ref name=biz/>
=== Judiciary === The Bangladeshi judicial system is inefficient and under the influence of the executive branch. Political appointments, promotions, and firings are routine, and it can be difficult to enforce contracts and resolve disputes.<ref name=trans/> The payment of bribes in exchange for favourable verdicts is common. Prosecutors, who earn only $37.50 ??? a month, are especially susceptible to bribery.<ref name=biz/>
In 2010, Judiciary of Bangladesh was ranked as the most corrupt institution of the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/south-asia/politicians-judiciary-most-corrupt-in-bangladesh_861288.html|title=Politicians, judiciary most corrupt in Bangladesh|date=10 July 2013|newspaper=Zee Bangladesh has a huge backlog of unresolved cases both civil and criminal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2016/04/01/bangladesh-judiciary-plans-evening-courts-to-clear-huge-case-backlog-in-districts|title=Bangladesh judiciary plans evening courts to clear huge case backlog in districts|newspaper=bdnews24.com|access-date=30 January 2017}}</ref> Political clout is believed to be the main factor behind most of the unsolved murder cases.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.dhakatribune.com/law-rights/2014/aug/16/political-clout-behind-most-unsolved-murder-cases|title=Political clout behind most unsolved murder cases {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|website=archive.dhakatribune.com|language=en|access-date=29 January 2017}}</ref>

==== Politics of trial ==== In Bangladesh, generally government files politically motivated cases against oppositions, and these cases get withdrawn or quashed when they gets to the government again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/withdrawal-of-political-cases-rule-of-law-stripped-away-14759|title=Withdrawal of political cases: Rule of law stripped away|date=10 March 2014|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=30 January 2017}}</ref>

===Bangladesh Military=== Although, Bangladesh Military is uniformed soldiers but Bangladesh military also involved large scale corruption in Bangladesh through Military's business empire. Bangladesh military officers are known to receiving illicit loans from the Trust Bank and VDP bank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thediplomat.com/2018/03/the-trouble-with-bangladesh-military/|title=The Trouble with Bangladesh Military|website=The Diplomat|access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref> The Bangladesh Rifles (BDR) mutiny was partly fueled by resentment among the BDR troops over the corruption of army officers who lead them for many years were personally profiting from consumer goods sold by the organisation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-south-asia-10801268/|title=Bangladesh army's advancing business interests|website=BBC News|access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref>
In the year 2012, Deffence Adviser Maj Gen (Retd) Tarique Ahmed Siddique was involved in bribery of BDT 7 million carried by a government vehicle. The vehicle with the money was confiscated by the Border Guard Bangladesh. Maj Gen (Retd) Tarique Ahmed Siddique called the then chief of army staff, General Md Abdul Mubeen to released the vehicle and the money. Intelligence sources reported that the Army chief was paid a large some of the money to release the vehicle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.srilankaguardian.org/2012/04/bangladesh-chief-of-army-staff-into.html/|title=BANGLADESH: Chief of army staff into the corruption business|website=Srilanka Guardian|access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref>

=== Energy and power ===
=== Banking === In 2015, it was revealed that some Bangladeshi accounts of [[HSBC]] were involved in money laundering activities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://archive.newagebd.net/93938/bangladeshi-accounts-linked-to-hsbc-tax-scandal/|title=Bangladeshi accounts linked to HSBC tax scandal – New Age|date=10 February 2015|newspaper=New Age|language=en-GB|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref> [[HSBC]] was also involved in tax evasion activities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bdchronicle.com/detail/news/32/14529|title=Tax evasion scandal: Bangladesh Bank to inspect HSBC's local office {{!}} Bdchronicle.com|website=BD Chronilce|language=en|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref>
=== Health and hygiene === A 2012 Survey by Transparency International Bangladesh showed that 40.2% of the people fell victim to the irregularities and corruptions in public hospitals.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/health/2014/nov/07/tib-health-sector-sickened-bribery-and-corruption|title=TIB: Health sector sickened with bribery and corruption|last=Azad|first=Abid|date=7 November 2014|newspaper=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=25 May 2016}}</ref> Doctors, nurses and other professionals working in government-run public hospitals have long been accused of demanding bribes for services which are supposed to be provided free of cost.<ref name="irinhealth">{{citation|title=Activists are calling for stronger action to address rising levels of corruption in Bangladesh's troubled public health care system|date=12 February 2013|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/97454/bangladeshi-health-sector-corruption-hits-poor-hardest|author=A.M. Badrudduza|publisher=irinnews.org}}</ref> The survey also alleged that the recruitment, transfer and promotion process of personnel in this sector is also corrupted.<ref name=":0" /> Although the allegations were rejected by the Government Health Ministry.<ref name=":0" /> The survey reported that there is lack of regulation from the government in the private health care sector. The medical practitioners in these sector earn money by driving up health care costs and commission agreements with diagnostic centres.<ref>{{citation|title=TIB: Health sector sickened with bribery and corruption|date=7 November 2014|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/health/2014/nov/07/tib-health-sector-sickened-bribery-and-corruption|author=Abid Azad|publisher=Dhaka Tribune}}</ref> According to patients, even in emergency needs, they were unable to access services unless a bribe is paid first.<ref name="irinhealth" />
== Business == Companies have been reported to be subjected to expensive and useless license and permit requirements.<ref name="anticorruptionportal" /> In 2014–2015, business executives said corruption was the second largest obstacle to doing business in Bangladesh. Business people are often expected to bribe public officials, often in connection with annual taxes. Fully 48% of companies have been asked to pay bribes, and most firms seeking licenses are asked for bribes, with 55% of construction permits, 77% of import licenses, 56% of water connection arrangements and 48% of electricity connection arrangements involving bribes.<ref name=trans/>
Politicians are involved in giving contracts to foreign companies by taking bribes or kickbacks in closed-door negotiations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/bribe/2009/08/bangladesh-a-dirty-deal-back-fires.html|title=Bangladesh: The Blowback of Corruption|date=21 August 2009|website=PBS.org|publisher=WGBH Educational Foundation.|access-date=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2012/06/29/world-bank-statement-padma-bridge|title=World Bank Statement on Padma Bridge|date=29 June 2012|website=The World Bank|publisher=The World Bank|access-date=18 May 2016}}</ref> Major public contracts are often said to involve corruption. Fully 49% of companies said they had to present "gifts" to win state contracts, with those "gifts" averaging a value of 3% of the contract value.<ref name=trans/>
Business owners do not obey proper safety codes of the buildings and workplaces. As a result, several large accidents occurred and killed hundreds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/news/feature/in_bangladesh_corruption_kills_hundreds|title=In Bangladesh, corruption kills hundreds – Transparency International|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|website=www.transparency.org|access-date=18 May 2016}}</ref> The garment industry is also rife with corruption, with leaders in the industry obtaining tax concessions, gaining special access to infrastructure, and ignoring with impunity official safety and security regulations. Because of this brand of corruption, the Rana Plaza factory complex collapsed, killing over 1200. Owing to corruption, the builders had been able to ignore many construction regulations.<ref name=trans/>
Various international sources provided $2.9 billion to build the Padma Multilateral Purpose Bridge near Dhaka in 2011. After the World Bank learned in 2012 of "a high-level corruption conspiracy among politicians, businessmen, and private individuals" in connection with the bridge, support for the project was withdrawn by several of the sources.<ref name=trans/>
Transparency International attributes the ubiquity and high level of corruption in Bangladesh to the power of business interests over the political parties and parliament.<ref name=biz/>

==Effect of corruption==
=== Money in Swiss banks === According to the data published by Swiss National Bank (SNB) on 29 June 2017, BDT 4423,00,00,00,000 in Swiss banks<ref name="bdn30Jun2017" /> which has been increased by 20% since 2013-14 .<ref name="fe27Jul2017" />
=== Foreign investment === According to the US report on the Bangladesh's investment climate,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/business/corruption-still-serious-impediment-investment-137005|title=Corruption still a serious impediment to investment|date=3 September 2015|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> <blockquote>''"Corruption is common in public procurement, tax and customs collection, and regulatory authorities. Corruption, including bribery, raises the costs and risks of doing business."''</blockquote>
==Anti-corruption==
=== Anti Corruption Commission === {{Main|Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh}} Anti Corruption Commission Bangladesh (ACC) was formed through an act promulgated on 23 February 2004 that came into force on 9 May 2004. The commission is often criticised for being ineffective and a wastage of resources due to the influence of the government over it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Syeda Naushin Parnini|first=|date=2011|year=|title=Governance Reforms and Anti-Corruption Commission in Bangladesh|url=http://www.sar.org.ro/polsci/?p=587|department=Governance and Corruption|journal=The Romanian Journal of Political Science|series=|language=en|volume=11|issue=1|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> The Anti-Corruption Commission of Bangladesh is crippled by the 2013 amendment<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/151739/bd-s-anti-corruption-body-made-ineffective|title=BD's anti-corruption body made ineffective|date=11 August 2005|newspaper=DAWN.COM|language=en|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref> of the Anti Corruption Commission Act introduced by the ruling [[Bangladesh Awami League|Awami League]] government, which makes it necessary for the commission to obtain permissions from the government to investigate or file any charge against government bureaucrats or politicians.<ref>{{citation|title=Anti-corruption Commission (Amendment) Bill Unconstitutional, discriminatory, self-defeating|date=14 November 2013|url=http://www.ti-bangladesh.org/beta3/index.php/en/report-s/3883-anti-corruption-commission-amendment-bill-unconstitutional-discriminatory-self-defeating|author=Iftekhar Zaman, Executive Director of Transparency International Bangladesh|accessdate=7 May 2016}}</ref>
In 2015, the ACC investigated the case of [[Padma Bridge Scandal]]. Even though the [[World Bank]] continuously pressed the government to take actions against the perpetrators, after 53 days' of investigation, ACC found nobody to be guilty. On the basis of ACC's report, Dhaka district judge court acquitted all the seven government officials who were believed to be involved in the corruption plot.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/all-padma-bridge-graft-accused-acquitted-47466|title=All Padma bridge graft accused acquitted|date=26 October 2014|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref> Before that, ACC even exonerated [[Syed Abul Hossain]] and ex-state minister for foreign affairs [[Abul Hasan Chowdhury]] from the allegation of involvement in the corruption conspiracy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://print.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2014/10/27/63153/print|title=The Financialexpress-bd|website=print.thefinancialexpress-bd.com|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref>
=== Transparency International Bangladesh === [[Transparency International Bangladesh]] (TIB) is an independent, non-government, non-partisan and non-profit organisation which is a fully accredited national chapter of Berlin-based [[Transparency International]] in Bangladesh. TIB undertakes research and surveys to investigate the magnitude and impact of corruption and suggest necessary moves for establishing a transparent system of governance, politics and business.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ti-bangladesh.org/beta3/index.php/en/about-us/vision-mission|title=Vision & Mission – Transparency International Bangladesh (TIB)|website=www.ti-bangladesh.org|access-date=23 May 2016}}</ref> The reports and researches published by TIB regarding corruptions are routinely rejected and overlooked by the Government and other responsible wings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/economy/news/92027/BGMEA-rejects-TIB-report-terming-it-baseless|title=BGMEA rejects TIB report terming it baseless|newspaper=Prothom Alo|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rmgbd.net/bkmea-rejects-tib-report-on-apparel-industry/|title=BKMEA rejects TIB report on apparel industry {{!}} RMG Bangladesh|last=Bangladesh|first=RMG|website=rmgbd.net|language=en-US|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://archive.newagebd.net/240383/passport-dept-rejects-tib-survey-public-service/|title=Passport dept rejects TIB survey on public service – New Age|date=15 July 2016|newspaper=New Age|language=en-GB|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/fbuta-rejects-tib-report-public-univs-1333837|title=FBUTA rejects TIB report on public univs|date=22 December 2016|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref>
==Corruption Index of Bangladesh==
The following table is depicting the comparison of [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] of various countries in South Asia as rated by Transparency International.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/research/cpi/overview|title=Research – CPI – Overview|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|website=www.transparency.org|access-date=28 April 2016}}</ref>
The Global Corruption Perception Index of 2016,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2016#table|title=CORRUPTION PERCEPTIONS INDEX 2016|last=Transperency|first=International|date=25 January 2017|website=www.transparency.org|publisher=Transperency International|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref> published on 25 January 2017 indicates that, even though Bangladesh gained one point in the ranking, it slept 6 positions to 145<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.benarnews.org/english/news/thai/corruption-01252017184534.html|title=Corruption on the Rise in Thailand, Bangladesh: Index|website=BenarNews|language=en|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/bangladesh-ranked-13th-most-corrupted-country-208054|title=Bangladesh 13th most corrupt country: TI|date=27 January 2016|newspaper=The Daily Star|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> as more countries had been able to reduce their corruption levels than that of Bangladesh. According to the report, India<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/India-in-red-zone-on-transparency-list/article17094505.ece|title=India in red zone on transparency list|last=Correspondent|first=Special|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> and Sri Lanka<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Sri-Lanka-becomes-more-corrupt-122724.html|title=Sri Lanka becomes more corrupt|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> both plunged in the ranking. The biggest improver was Pakistan<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/94131-Pakistan-leaves-China-India-behind-in-reducing-corruption|title=Pakistan leaves China, India behind in reducing corruption|website=www.thenews.com.pk|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref> as it gained two more points than that of 2015 and also progressed one step forward.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1235708|title=Pakistan only Saarc country to improve Corruption Perceptions Index score: TI|date=27 January 2016|newspaper=DAWN.COM|language=en|access-date=25 January 2017}}</ref>

== Visa Restriction Index of Bangladesh == According to the Arton Capital's Passport Index, Bangladeshi passport is ranked 6th worst in the world in terms of visa free travel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.passportindex.org/byRank.php?ccode=bd|title=Passport Index 2017 – World's passports in one place. – A global ranking of the world's passports.|newspaper=Passport Index – All the world's passports in one place.|language=en-US|access-date=28 January 2017}}</ref> Bangladeshi passport's visa free travel score is 35 as compared to Afghanistan 23, Bhutan 48, India 45, Nepal 37, Pakistan 26, Sri Lanka 35.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.passportindex.org/byRank.php|title=Passport Index 2017 – World's passports in one place. – A global ranking of the world's passports.|newspaper=Passport Index – All the world's passports in one place.|language=en-US|access-date=28 January 2017}}</ref>

{{about|the 1947–1949 trials held in Slovenia|the 1945–1947 trials held in Germany|Dachau trials|}}
The '''Dachau trials''' ({{lang-sl|Dachauski procesi}})<ref name="Ivanic">Ivanič, Martin. 1988. Dachauski procesi. ''Enciklopedija Slovenije'', vol. 2, p. 167. Ljubljana: Mladinska knjiga.</ref> in [[Slovenia]] were a group of [[show trial]]s held between 1947/48 and 1949. The name refers to the fact that 31 of the defendants had been prisoners at the [[Dachau concentration camp]].<ref name="Nečak">Nečak, Dušan. 1999. Dachauski procesi 1947–1949. ''Kronika'' 57: 533–542.</ref>
== Background and procedure == The trials marked a departure from previous communist show trials in Slovenia such as the [[Nagode Trial]] because until this point the authorities had sought enemies outside the Communist Party, among the non-proletariat and the non-communist intelligentsia. By selecting enemies from the ranks of the Communist Party, a Yugoslav version of the [[Moscow Trials|Stalinist show trials]] was launched.<ref name="Nečak"/>
In the preparations for the trials, a large number of writers, physicians, politicians, and engineers were arrested without knowing whether they would be accused or merely used as witnesses.<ref name="Repe">Repe, Božo. 1999. Politični sodni proces. ''Enciklopedija Slovenije'', vol. 9, pp. 94–99. Ljubljana: Mladinska knjiga, p. 98.</ref> Those arrested were tortured and deprived of their legal rights.<ref name="Nečak"/><ref name="Repe"/> Forged documents were prepared as evidence against them and false testimony was prepared.<ref name="Repe"/>
The defendants in the trials were forced to confess to being Nazi spies while imprisoned at the Dachau concentration camp, collaborating with the Gestapo, and working for Western powers after the Second World War in order to undermine socialism.<ref>Job, Cvijeto. 2002. ''Yugoslavia's Ruin: The Bloody Lessons of Nationalism, a Patriot's Warning''. Lanham, MD: Rowman & Littlefield, p. 44.</ref><ref name="Revolution">Lenin, Vladimir Ilʹich (ed. Slavoj Žižek). 2002. ''Revolution at the Gates: A Selection of Writings from February to October 1917''. London: Verso, p. 330.</ref><ref name="Land">Luthar, Oto (ed.). 2002. ''The Land Between: A History of Slovenia''. Frankfurt am Main: Peter Lang, pp. 453–454.</ref> The proceedings were broadcast to the public via special loudspeakers on the streets.<ref name="Repe"/> Most of the defendants were shot immediately after being condemned to death, and others were sent to the [[Goli Otok]] prison camp.<ref name="Revolution"/> The total number of people executed, the specific dates when they were killed, and where their bodies were disposed of remains unknown.<ref name="Land"/> Some are believed to lie in the forest near [[Kočevje]], and others in Ljubljana's [[Žale]] cemetery.<ref name="Nečak"/>
The sentences handed down in the trials were reversed in April 1986 at the Tenth Congress of the [[League of Communists of Slovenia]].<ref name="Ivanic"/><ref name="Nečak"/><ref name="Repe"/><ref name="Land"/>
== List of trials == * Preliminary trial: the trial of Janko Pufler (May 24, 1947)<ref name="Land"/><ref name="Repe"/> * First Dachau Trial: the trial of Branko Diehl and Stane Oswald (April 21–26, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/><ref name="Land"/> * Second Dachau Trial: the trial of Jože Mavec and Franc Malenšek (May 12, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Third Dachau Trial: the trial of Mitja Sark (May 22, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Fourth Dachau Trial: the trial of Franc Žumer and Alojz Veršnik (May 26, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Fifth Dachau Trial: the trial of Janko Ravnikar (July 20, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Sixth Dachau Trial: the trial of Vlasto (Vladimir) Kopač, Andrej Bohinc, Viljem Brezar, and Roman Vidmar (August 10, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Seventh Dachau Trial: the trial of Rezika Barle (August 18, 1948)<ref name="Repe"/> * Eighth Dachau Trial: the trial of Vekoslav Figar and Ivan Ranzinger (June 29, 1949)<ref name="Repe"/> * Ninth Dachau Trial: the trial of Jože Marčan (September 20, 1949)<ref name="Repe"/> * Tenth Dachau Trial: the trial of [[Igor Torkar|Boris Fakin]] (Igor Torkar), [[Ludvik Mrzel]], and Marjan Petrak (October 11, 1949)<ref name="Land"/><ref name="Repe"/>
== Overview == * The proceedings involved 7,380 Slovenes and 2,144 foreign citizens.<ref name="Nečak"/> * 37 people were sentenced,<ref name="Nečak"/> 15 of them to be shot to death, four of whom were not executed.<ref name="Nečak"/><ref name="Repe"/> * 10 people were shot (either on May 12, 1948 and January 5, 1949, or on November 18, 1950, probably in the forest near [[Kočevje]]).<ref name="Nečak"/> * 20 people were sentenced to forced labor, one of whom died at the Goli Otok prison camp.<ref name="Nečak"/> * The judicial investigation against three people was suspended.<ref name="Nečak"/> * Three people died during interrogations.<ref name="Nečak"/> * Investigators: Lieutenant Colonel Ivan More (a.k.a. Žan; head), Kamilo Hilbert, Branko Ivanuš, Nace Majcen, Martin Renko, Franc Pirkovič, Karlo Sagadin, Rado Škraba, Aleks Winkler.

{{Information security}} '''Data-centric security''' is an approach to security that emphasizes the security of the [[data]] itself rather than the security of [[Computer network|networks]], [[Server (computing)|servers]], or applications. Data-centric security is evolving rapidly as enterprises increasingly rely on digital information to [[business process|run their business]] and [[big data]] projects become mainstream. {{cite web | last = Gartner Group | title =Gartner Says Big Data Needs a Data-Centric Security Focus | date = 2014 | url = http://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/2758717 }} {{cite web | last = SANS Institute | title = Data-Centric Security Needed to Protect Big Data Implementations | date = 2015 | url = https://www.sans.org/press/announcement/2015/06/11/1 }} {{cite web | last = IRI | title = Masking Big Data in Hadoop and Very Large Databases | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iri.com/solutions/big-data/big-data-protection }} Data-centric security also allows organizations to overcome the disconnect between IT security technology and the objectives of business strategy by relating security services directly to the data they implicitly protect; a relationship that is often obscured by the presentation of security as an end in itself. {{cite web | last = IEEE | title = Elevating the Discussion on Security Management: The Data Centric Paradigm | date = 2007 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/4257215_Elevating_the_Discussion_on_Security_Management_The_Data_Centric_Paradigm }} == Key concepts == Common processes in a data-centric security model include:{{cite web | last = Wired Magazine | title = Information-Centric Security: Protect Your Data From the Inside-Out | date = 2014 | url = http://insights.wired.com/profiles/blogs/information-centric-security-protecting-your-data-from-the-inside#axzz3qZi5pQII }}
* Discover: the ability to know what data is stored where including sensitive information. * Manage: the ability to define access policies that will determine if certain data is accessible, editable, or blocked from specific users, or locations. * Protect: the ability to defend against data loss or unauthorized use of data and prevent sensitive data from being sent to unauthorized users or locations. * Monitor: the constant monitoring of data usage to identify meaningful deviations from normal behavior that would point to possible malicious intent. From a technical point of view, information(data)-centric security relies on the implementation of the following: {{cite web | last = Mogull | first = Rich | title =The Information-Centric Security Lifecycle | date = 2014 | url = https://securosis.com/assets/library/presentations/DataSecurityLifecycle-PDF.pdf }}
* Information (data) that is self-describing and defending. * Policies and controls that account for business context. * Information that remains protected as it moves in and out of applications and storage systems, and changing business context. * Policies that work consistently through the different data management technologies and defensive layers implemented. == Technology == ===Data access controls and policies=== Data [[access control]] is the selective restriction of access to data. Accessing may mean viewing, editing, or using. Defining proper access controls requires to map out the information, where it resides, how important it is, who it is important to, how sensitive the data is and then designing appropriate controls. {{cite web | last = Federal News Radio | title = NASA Glenn becoming more data-centric across many fronts | date = 2015 | url = http://federalnewsradio.com/technology/2015/11/nasa-glenn-becoming-data-centric-across-many-fronts/ }} ===Encryption=== {{main|Encryption}} Encryption is a proven data-centric technique to address the risk of data theft in smartphones, laptops, desktops and even servers, including the cloud. One limitation is that encryption is not always effective once a network intrusion has occurred and cybercriminals operate with stolen valid user credentials. Encryption solutions with multi-factor authentication are much more effective in preventing such access. {{cite web | last = MIT Technology Review | title = Encryption Wouldn’t Have Stopped Anthem’s Data Breach | date = 2015 | url = http://www.technologyreview.com/view/535111/encryption-wouldnt-have-stopped-anthems-data-breach/ }} ===Data masking=== {{main|Data masking}} Data Masking is the process of hiding specific data within a database table or cell to ensure that data security is maintained and that sensitive information is not exposed to unauthorized personnel. This may include masking the data from users, developers, third-party and outsourcing vendors, etc. Data masking can be achieved multiple ways: by duplicating data to eliminate the subset of the data that needs to be hidden, or by obscuring the data dynamically as users perform requests. {{cite web | last = IRI | title = Dynamic Data Masking Software | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iri.com/solutions/data-masking/dynamic-data-masking }} ===Auditing=== {{main|Security audit}} Monitoring all activity at the data layer is a key component of a data-centric security strategy. It provides visibility into the types of actions that users and tools have requested and been authorized to on specific data elements. Continuous monitoring at the data layer combined with precise access control can contribute significantly to the real-time detection of data breaches, limits the damages inflicted by a breach and can even stop the intrusion if proper controls are in place. A 2016 survey {{cite web | last = Dark Reading | title = Databases Remain Soft Underbelly Of Cybersecurity | date = 2016 | url = http://www.darkreading.com/application-security/database-security/databases-remain-soft-underbelly-of-cybersecurity/d/d-id/1325216 }} shows that most organizations still don't assess database activity continuously and lack the capability to identify database breaches in a timely fashion. == Cloud computing == [[Cloud computing]] is an evolving paradigm with tremendous momentum, but its unique aspects exacerbate security and privacy challenges. Heterogeneity and diversity of cloud services and environments demand fine-grained access control policies and services that should be flexible enough to capture dynamic, context, or attribute-based access requirements and data protection. {{cite web | last = IEEE | title = Security and Privacy Challenges in Cloud Computing Environments | date = 2010 | url = http://csis.pace.edu/~marchese/SE765/Paper/security2.pdf }} ===Data-centric security in the public cloud environments=== In recent decades many organizations rely on managing database services in public clouds such [[Amazon Web Services]], [[Oracle Cloud]], [[Google Cloud Platform]] or [[Microsoft Azure]] to organize their data. Such approach has its own limitations on what users can do with managing security of their sensitive data. For instance, hardware security appliances or agents running on the database servers are no longer an option. This requires innovative ways to secure data and databases such as using reverse proxy sitting between clients / applications and database servers. The requirements such supporting a load balancing, high availability and fail-over in data-centric security brings additional challenges that database security vendors must meet. {{cite web | last = DataSunrise | title = Data-centric database security in the public clouds | date = 2017 | url = https://www.datasunrise.com/blog/database-security-in-the-cloud }} == See also == {{Portal|Information technology}} * [[Data masking]] * [[Data security]] * [[Defense in depth (computing)]] * [[Information security]] * [[Information security policies]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Big data]]

{{other uses}} {{Marxism–Leninism sidebar|History}} '''De-Stalinization''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: десталинизация, ''destalinizatsiya'') consisted of a series of political reforms in the [[Soviet Union]] after the death of long-time leader [[Joseph Stalin]] in 1953, and the ascension of [[Nikita Khrushchev]] to power.<ref name="World Transformed p. 153">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/907585907|title=The world transformed: 1945 to the present|last=H.|first=Hunt, Michael|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780199371020|location=|pages=153|oclc=907585907}}</ref>
The reforms consisted of changing or removing key institutions that helped Stalin hold power: the [[Stalin's cult of personality|cult of personality that surrounded him]], the [[Stalinism|Stalinist political system]], and the [[Gulag|Gulag labour-camp system]], all of which had been created and dominated by him. Stalin was succeeded by a [[collective leadership]] after his death in March 1953, consisting of [[Georgi Malenkov]], [[Premier of the Soviet Union]]; [[Lavrentiy Beria]], head of the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Russia)#Soviet era|Ministry of the Interior]]; and Nikita Khrushchev, [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|First Secretary]] of the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Central Committee]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).
==Terminology issues== The term "de-Stalinization" is one which gained currency in both [[Russia]] and the [[Western world]] following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]], and was never used during the [[Khrushchev era]]. However, de-Stalinization efforts were set forth at this time by [[Nikita Khrushchev]] and the [[Government of the Soviet Union]] under the guise of the "overcoming/exposure of the cult of personality", with a heavy criticism of [[Joseph Stalin]]'s "era of the cult of personality".<ref name="Jones2006">{{cite book|author=Polly Jones|title=The Dilemmas of De-Stalinization: Negotiating Cultural and Social Change in the Khrushchev Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7dYiQYo1nwC&pg=PA2|date=7 April 2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-28347-7|pages=2–4}}</ref> However, prior to [[On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences|Khrushchev's "Secret Speech"]] to the [[20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th Party Congress]], no direct association between Stalin as a person and "the cult of personality" was openly made by Khrushchev or others within the party, although archival documents show that strong criticism of Stalin and [[Stalinism|his ideology]] featured in private discussions by Khruschchev at the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]].<ref name="Jones2006"/>
=="Silent de-Stalinization"== There were dangers in denouncing Stalin as he was placed on a pedestal both at home and among [[communists]] abroad.<ref>{{cite book|title=National Republic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vh7nAAAAMAAJ|year=1956|page=9|volume=44–45}}</ref> In the years 1953–1955, a period of "silent de-Stalinization" took place, as the revision of Stalin's policies was done in secret, and often with no explanation. This period saw a number of non-publicised [[Rehabilitation (Soviet)|political rehabilitations]],<ref name="Adler2004">{{cite book|author=Nanci Adler|title=The Gulag Survivor: Beyond the Soviet System|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pxtCbSg293gC&pg=PA21|date=1 February 2004|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=978-1-4128-3712-5|pages=21–22}}</ref> (such as Marshal [[Mikhail Tukhachevsky]], [[Politburo]] members [[Robert Eikhe]] and [[Jānis Rudzutaks]], and those executed in the [[Leningrad Affair]]<ref name="Boterbloem2013">{{cite book|author=Kees Boterbloem|title=A History of Russia and Its Empire: From Mikhail Romanov to Vladimir Putin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xbivAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA261|date=28 August 2013|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-0-7425-6840-2|page=261}}</ref>) and the release of "[[Article 58 (RSFSR Penal Code)|Article 58ers]]".<ref name="Adler2004" /> However, due to the huge influx of prisoners returning from the camps (90,000 prisoners in 1954–55 alone), this could not continue.<ref name="Adler2004" />
In December 1955 Khrushchev proposed a commission to be set up in order to investigate Stalin's activities on behalf of the Presidium; this investigation found out that out of the 1,920,635 arrested for anti-Soviet activities – who were arrested on fabricated evidence in the first place and confessed under [[torture]] authorized by Stalin – 688,503 were executed.<ref name="Swedin2010">{{cite book|author=Eric G. Swedin|title=When Angels Wept: A What-If History of the Cuban Missile Crisis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SmtoE-wxXCcC&pg=PA75|year=2010|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=978-1-59797-565-0|page=75}}</ref>
==Khrushchev's "Secret Speech"== [[File:First edition of Krushchev's "Secret Speech".jpg|thumb|''O kulcie jednostki i jego następstwach'', Warsaw, March 1956, first edition of the Secret Speech, published for the inner use in the [[PUWP]].]] De-Stalinization meant an end to the role of large-scale [[labor camp|forced labour]] in the economy. The process of freeing [[Gulag]] prisoners was started by [[Lavrentiy Beria]]. He was soon removed from power, arrested on 26 June 1953, and executed on 24 December 1953. [[Nikita Khrushchev]] emerged as the most powerful Soviet politician.<ref>[http://www.soviethistory.org/index.php?page=subject&SubjectID=1954succession&Year=1954 soviethistory.org]</ref>
While de-Stalinization was quietly underway ever since Stalin's death, the watershed event was Khrushchev's speech entitled "[[On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences]]", concerning Stalin. On 25 February 1956, he spoke to a closed session of the [[20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th Party Congress]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]], delivering an address laying out some of Stalin's crimes and the "conditions of insecurity, fear, and even desperation" created by Stalin.<ref name="World Transformed p. 153" /> Khrushchev shocked his listeners by denouncing Stalin's dictatorial rule and his [[cult of personality]] as inconsistent with communist and Party ideology. Among other points, he condemned the treatment of the [[Old Bolshevik]]s, people who had supported communism before the revolution, many of whom Stalin had executed as traitors. Khrushchev also attacked the crimes committed by associates of Beria.
===Motivation=== One reason given for Khrushchev's speech was his moral conscience; [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] said that Khrushchev spoke out of a "movement of the heart". This, the Communists believed, would prevent a fatal loss of self-belief and restore unity within the Party.<ref name="History Today.1">{{cite journal|last1=Cavendish|first1=Richard|title=Stalin Denounced by Nikita Khrushchev|journal=History Today|date=2 February 2006|volume=56|issue=2|url=http://www.historytoday.com/richard-cavendish/stalin-denounced-nikita-khrushchev|accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>
[[Martin McCauley (historian)|Martin McCauley]] argues that Khrushchev's purpose was to "liberate Party officials from the fear of repression". Khrushchev argued that if the Party were to be an efficient mechanism, stripped from the brutal abuse of power by any individual, it could transform the Soviet Union as well as the entire world.<ref name="McCauley2014">{{cite book|author=Martin McCauley|title=The Khrushchev Era 1953-1964|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MYuwCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43|date=9 September 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-88922-9|pages=43–44}}</ref>
However, others have suggested that the speech was made in order to deflect blame from the Communist Party or the principles of [[Marxism–Leninism]] and place the blame squarely on Stalin's shoulders, thus preventing a more radical debate.<ref name="History Today.1" /> However, the publication of this speech caused many party members to resign in protest, both abroad and within the Soviet Union.<ref name="History Today.1" /><ref name="Boterbloem2013" />
By attacking Stalin, McCauley argues, he was undermining the credibility of Molotov, Malenkov, Kaganovich and other political opponents who had been within "Stalin's inner circle" during the 1930s more than he had been. If they did not "come over to Khrushchev", they "risk[ed] being banished with Stalin" and associated with his dictatorial control.<ref name="McCauley2014" />
==Changes== ===Improved prison conditions=== Khrushchev attempted to make the Gulag labour system less harsh, by allowing prisoners to post letters home to their families, and by allowing family members to mail clothes to prisoners, which was not allowed under Stalin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulaghistory.org/nps/downloads/gulag-curriculum.pdf |title=Gulag : Soviet Prison Camps and their Legacy |publisher=Gulaghistory.org |accessdate=2013-10-12}}</ref> When Stalin died, the Gulag was "radically reduced in size".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulaghistory.org/nps/onlineexhibit/stalin/ |title=Gulag: Soviet Forced Labor Camps and the Struggle for Freedom |publisher=Gulaghistory.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-12}}</ref> On 25 October 1956, a resolution of the CPSU declared that the existence of the Gulag labour system was "inexpedient".<ref name="memo">[[Memorial (society)|Memorial]] http://www.memo.ru/history/nkvd/gulag/Articles/chapter3main.htm</ref> The Gulag institution was closed by the MVD order No 020 of 25 January 1960.<ref name="memo1">[[Memorial (society)|Memorial]] http://www.memo.ru/history/NKVD/GULAG/r1/r1-4.htm</ref>
===Re-naming of places and buildings=== Khrushchev renamed or reverted the names of many [[List of places named after Joseph Stalin|places bearing Stalin's name]], including cities, territories, landmarks, and other facilities.<ref name=bursa1985>{{cite journal |title=Political Changes of Names of Soviet Towns |author= G.R.F. Bursa |journal= Slavonic and East European Review |volume= 63 |year= 1985 }}</ref> The [[State Anthem of the Soviet Union]] was purged of references to Stalin. The Stalin-centric and [[World War II]]-era lines in the lyrics were effectively excised when an [[instrumental]] version replaced it. The [[Palace of Culture and Science|Joseph Stalin Palace of Culture and Science]] in [[Warsaw]], Poland was renamed in 1956.
===Destruction of monuments=== [[File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-11500-0497,_Berlin,_Karl-Marx-Allee,_Denkmal_Stalin.jpg|thumb|The [[Stalin Statue (Berlin)|Statue of Stalin]] on Stalinallee in Berlin-Friedrichshain was removed in 1961.]]
The [[Yerevan]] monument was removed in spring 1962 and replaced by [[Mother Armenia]] in 1967. Thousands of [[List of statues of Stalin|Stalin monuments]] have been destroyed not only in the Soviet Union, but in other former Communist countries. In November 1961, the large [[Stalin Statue (Berlin)|Stalin Statue]] on Berlin's monumental Stalinallee (promptly renamed [[Karl-Marx-Allee]]) was removed in a clandestine operation. The [[Stalin Monument (Budapest)|Monument in Budapest]] was destroyed in October 1956. The biggest one, the [[Stalin Monument (Prague)|Prague monument]], was taken down in November 1962.
===Re-location of Stalin's body=== Given momentum by these public renamings, the process of de-Stalinization peaked in 1961 during the [[22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|22nd Congress of the CPSU]]. Two climactic acts of de-Stalinization marked the meetings: first, on 31 October 1961, Stalin's body was moved from [[Lenin's Mausoleum]] in [[Red Square]] to a location near the Kremlin wall;<ref name="cnnthisday">{{Cite journal|title=CNN Interactive - Almanac - October 31|publisher=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/almanac/9810/31/#today|quote=''(October 31) 1961, Russia's de-Stalinisation program reached a climax when his body was removed from the mausoleum in Red Square and re-buried.''|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> second, on 11 November 1961, the "hero city" Stalingrad was renamed Volgograd.<ref name="nytimes_namechanged">{{Cite news|title=Stalingrad Name Changed|date=1961-11-11|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|quote=''MOSCOW, Saturday, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- The "Hero City" of Stalingrad has been renamed Volgograd, the Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today.''|author=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1961/11/11/archives/stalingrad-name-changed.html|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
==Extent of de-Stalinization== Contemporary historians regard the beginning of de-Stalinization as a turning point in the [[history of the Soviet Union]] that began during the [[Khrushchev Thaw]]. It subsided during the [[History of the Soviet Union (1964–82)|Brezhnev period]] until the mid-1980s, and accelerated again with the policies of ''[[perestroika]]'' and ''[[glasnost]]'' under [[Mikhail Gorbachev]].
De-Stalinization has been considered a fragile process. Historian Polly Jones said that "re-Stalinization" was highly likely after a brief period of "thaw".<ref name="Jones2006" /> [[Anne Applebaum]] agrees: "The era which came to be called the 'Thaw' was indeed an era of change, but change of a particular kind: reforms took two steps forward, and then one step—or sometimes three steps—back."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Applebaum|first1=Anne|title=Gulag: A History|date=2003|publisher=Doubleday|isbn=9780767900560|chapter=Thaw – and Release}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Anti-fascism]] *[[Anti-Stalinist left]] *[[History of the Soviet Union (1953–1964)]]: De-Stalinization and the Khrushchev era *[[Kureika (village)]] *[[List of places named after Joseph Stalin]] *[[Denazification]] *[[Decommunization]]
